quote: Neither story raises the possibility that blocking Facebook is pointless because it's likely to just irritate your employees without making them more productive. There is an infinite number of ways to procrastinate, from personal phone calls and emails to chatting with co-workers to taking a nap at your desk. They also don't mention that allowing your users to surf at work can lead to happier, more loyal employees who will more than make up for their lost productivity at work by doing work-related surfing at home.

My approach here is never to act like I know the right answer, but instead to try and assess why I think the other person is wrong. Is it because they're actually wrong? Or have I misunderstood what they said? Or do I have bad information or assumptions?

I always try to figure out the least number of probative questions I can ask (not rhetorical) that will set the matter straight. This way, if I am wrong somehow, I have a chance to understand what's really going on without having publicly established a point of view.

If I'm right, my questions should make clear that I'm right by the answers I get. More importantly, the answers can make clear whether the person wants the truth or just wants their way, which is often more valuable info than settling the truth.

It is a mistake to let people be wrong if they were actually after the truth and would have appreciated a correction. It's tempting to let people be wrong and fall into this political mindset about everything, but it just perpetuates itself. Not everyone is worried more about their pride than what makes sense.
